Spark's Environmental Policy sets out our expectations for our people to consider environmental impacts when making decisions at work, including examining our business practices, understanding their consequences, and taking reasonable steps to reduce our ecological footprint. The Policy was first introduced in FY21, and since that time, we have implemented an online training programme for all employees who want to learn about our approach to sustainability and their expectations to consider environmental impacts in their day-to-day activities.

Spark has formal governance processes for most material environmental topics, particularly energy use and emissions. Spark measures and reports their energy use and emissions every quarter, with this information shared in updates to their Technology Leadership Team, who act as a governance group for our emissions reduction work.

Emissions performance refers to how well an entity, such as a company or a product, manages and minimizes its greenhouse gas emissions. Therefore, assessing emissions performance is an essential aspect of environmental sustainability.

Spark also reports our emissions performance and quarterly sustainability KPIs to our Leadership Squad. The Leadership Squad is a steering committee for sustainability across Spark through a standing quarterly agenda item at their regular meetings.

Spark is a founding member of the Climate Leaders Coalition (CLC). The CLC is a group of CEOs committed to voluntary action on climate change, measuring and publicly reporting their emissions and setting an absolute target for reducing emissions in line with the Paris Agreement.

Spark has committed to a government-accredited voluntary product stewardship scheme for mobile phones, which the Re Mobile initiative implements. The RE: MOBILE scheme was one of the first industry schemes voluntarily accredited by the Ministry for the Environment (MfE) under the provisions of the Act.

Spark is a member of the Digital Boost Alliance, a Government-led initiative that brings together the public and corporate sectors. The initiative is set to help small and medium businesses and individuals across Aotearoa lift their use of digital technologies.
